Through  its  interventions  in  the  road  sector  in  Sri  Lanka,  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) is supporting the establishment of a policy and 
institutional framework to improve overall sector performance. This will be 
achieved through a series of interventions over the period 2002-2008. The 
proposed Project will be the first in the series of interventions, supporting 
the  first  stage  of  the  reform  program  and  financing  improvement  of 
provincial  roads.  Technical  assistance  (TA)  will  also  be  provided  to 
prepare the second intervention in the sector. 
 
Efficient  transport  contributes  to  the  expansion  of  economic  opportunities 
and the reduction of poverty. The overall contribution of road infrastructure 
requires  institutional  arrangements  and  capacity  that  support  strategic 
management of the sector, planning and management of investments and 
maintenance,  and  competitive  provision  of  civil  works  and  of  engineering 
and related services. Sustained institutional reforms are needed to enable 
the Road Development Authority (RDA) and provincial councils to perform 
their strategic, planning, and management roles, and to establish a strong, 
competitive  private  sector.  A  further  determinant  of  transport  efficiency  is 
the performance of transport services that make use of road infrastructure. 
There  is  a  need  to  improve  the  regulatory  framework  for  bus  services  to 
realize  the  potential  contribution  of  the  private  sector  while  safeguarding 
the  interests  of  passengers.  There  is  also  a  need  for  investment  in 
improvement of the road network, both to expand capacity in response to 
rising  traffic  on  the  national  highway  network  and  to  address  poor  road 
conditions on parts of the provincial road network. 
 
The  overall  objective  of  the  Project  is  to  advance  policy  and  institutional 
reforms to create an enabling environment for the efficient and sustainable 
development of the road sector with substantial participation of the private 
sector.  The  medium-term  policy  framework  developed  and  agreed  upon 
with  the  Government  will  serve  as  a  roadmap  for  future  lending  to  Sri 
Lanka’s road sector. 
 
The  proposed  Project  and  its  attached  TAs  are  designed  to  achieve  two 
specific  objectives:  The  first  is  to  improve  transport  efficiency  by  (i) 
strengthening  the  performance  of  the  road  sector institutions responsible 
for  the  national  and  provincial  road  networks,  (ii)  improving  road 
maintenance  and  road  maintenance  funding,  (iii)  developing  streamlined

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

2. 
Sri Lanka has a road network of about 83,690 kilometers (km), comprising about 11,460 
km of NHs (Classes A and B), 13,880 km of provincial roads (PRs, Classes C, D, and E),2 and 
58,350  km  of  local  authority  roads.  Road  transport  accounts  for  about  92%  of  passenger  and 
freight land transport. Vehicle ownership and road traffic have grown rapidly. The total number 
of registered vehicles was about 1.4 million in 1997, increasing at 6% per annum. Of the total of 
67  billion  passenger-km  of  travel  in  2000,  33.6  billion  were  on  private  buses,  19.7  billion  on 
public buses, 3.2 billion on railways, and 10.5 billion on private vehicles.  
 
3. 
While  the  road  network  is  extensive,  most  roads  were  built  more  than  50  years  ago. 
Road  maintenance,  rehabilitation,  and  new  construction  have  not  kept  abreast  of  the  rapid 
growth in demand for transport. Traffic levels now exceed the design capacity of many roads. 
Due  to  neglect  of  road  maintenance,  road  conditions  are  often  poor.  Uncontrolled  roadside 
development has also reduced the capacity of the network. This has negative consequences for 
road user costs, road safety, and the quality and frequency of transport services, and limits the 
contribution of roads to national development, economic growth, and poverty reduction.  
 
4. 
The  public  sector  retains  most  of  the  responsibilities  for  the  provision  of  NHs.  This 
includes not only planning and managing the road network, but also designing and supervising 
the  road  works.  The  role  of  the  domestic  private  sector  in  road  contracting  and  engineering 
services is underdeveloped compared with other ADB developing member countries. 
 
The  Ministry  of  Transport,  Highways  and  Civil  Aviation  (MTHCA)  has  overall 
5. 
responsibility for policies and programs concerning national transport. The Ministry of Highways 
(MOH)  has  overall  responsibility  for  programs  and  projects  for  NHs.  The  Road  Development 
Authority  (RDA),3  a  statutory  institution  assigned  to  MOH,  is  responsible  for  planning  and 
managing  the  development  of  NHs,  and  for  maintenance.  Although  having  the  structure  of  a 
commercial  organization,  with  a  chairman,  general  manager,  and  a  board  of  directors,  in 
practice  RDA  operates  as  a  government  department  under  MOH,  with  relatively  limited 
autonomy.  Most  of  RDA’s  engineering,  construction  and  maintenance  works  is  carried  out  by 
the  Road  Construction  and  Development  Company  (RCDC),  owned  by  RDA,  on  the  basis  of 
work orders with remuneration based on highways schedule of rates plus overhead markups.

arrangements for carrying out road responsibilities. Several different structures were adopted for

council,  and  establishing  a  separate  provincial  road  development  authority.  There  is  a  lack  of

7. 
In 1999, a survey of PRs conducted in North Central, North Western, Uva, and Western 
provinces found that the network was generally in poor condition, with a wide range of width and 
geometric standards. Potholes and breakup of bitumen surfacing were the most common form 
of  deterioration,  and  in  most  cases  reconstruction  or  overlay  was  needed.  It  was  evident  that 
relatively little rehabilitation and periodic maintenance had been carried out in the previous 10 
years.  The  survey  found  that  (i)  11%  of  the  network  was  in  good  or  very  good  condition  and 
would  not  need  rehabilitation  for  some  years;  (ii)  15%  was  in  fair  condition  and  likely  to  need 
resurfacing  within  the  next  5  years;  (iii)  54%  was  in  poor  condition  and  needed  major 
rehabilitation  to  return  the  roads  to  a  maintainable  condition  and  provide  all-weather 
serviceability; and (iv) 20% was in very poor condition, requiring reconstruction.  
 
8. 
Freight services in Sri Lanka are operated by the private sector and are not controlled. 
There  are  associations  and  cooperatives  that  represent  freight  operators.  The  freight  haulage 
market is highly competitive. Haulage rates vary for different commodities. The rates on roads in 
poor condition are about 20% higher than on roads in good condition. 
 
9. 
Passenger bus services are the leading form of public transport in Sri Lanka and perform 
an important role in providing transport for poor people and those living in remote areas, and in 
enabling  them  to  have  access  to  economic  opportunities  and  services.  In  2000,  there  were 
16,167  licensed  private  buses  and  5,894  public  buses.  Private  services  met  63%  of  the 
passenger-km and public services met 37%. The standard of bus services is generally low, with 
problems in terms of service coverage, quality of service, safety, and reliability.  
 
10. 
There  have  been  numerous  changes  in  responsibilities  for  bus  services.  Bus  services 
were operated by the private companies, which were nationalized and consolidated into a single 
public  company,  the  Ceylon  Transport  Board,  in  1958.  In  1978,  this  was  dissolved  and  its 
functions  were  divided  among  nine  regional  transport  boards  and  the  Sri  Lanka  Central 
Transport  Board.  In  1979, to supplement the services, private bus services were reintroduced 
and  route  associations  were  established,  which  were  disbanded  by  the  late  1980s.  In  1991,  a 
National  Transport  Commission  was  established  to  formulate  policy  and  disburse  subsidies. 
Provincial  transport  commissions  were  also  established  to  regulate  intraprovincial  services.  In 
the  early  1990s,  the  regional  transport  boards  were  transformed  into  93  peoplized  bus 
companies,  under  which  the  Government  provided  employees  with  50%  shares  of  the mobile 
assets. These were reconsolidated into 11 regional transport companies in 1997.  
 
11. 
Neither private nor public bus services have achieved efficiency and good service for a 
sustained  period.  Changes  in  policy  and  institutional  arrangements  sometimes  led  to  a 
temporary improvement in service, but was generally followed by declining service performance, 
necessitating  further  change.  Nationalization,  route  associations,  and  the  establishment  of 
transport commis sions, as well as resumption of private services and successive restructurings

B. 
 
 
 
13. 
The  existing  institutional  arrangements  have  led  to  problems  of  inefficiency,  lack  of 
capacity, and inadequate maintenance. A series of interconnected weaknesses in RDA includes 
(i) lack of capacity to systematically plan, program, and prioritize road development options; (ii) 
lack  of  preconstruction  processes  needed  for  advance  preparation  and  planning  of  complex 
projects;  (iii)  lack  of  experience  in  use  of  employer-contractor  contracts  needed  for  effective 
management and control of civil works construction; (iv) lack of systems for road maintenance 
management,  including  planning,  budgeting,  programming,  and  controlling;  (v)  absence  of  a 
technical audit function; and (vi) inadequate level of road maintenance funding.  
 
An  underlying  cause  of  many  of  these  problems  was  RDA’s  reliance  on  RCDC.  The 
14. 
automatic use of RCDC to execute most domestically funded road works meant there was no 
pipeline  of  domestic  work  to  support  the  development  of  domestic  private  sector capacity in 
road contracting and engineering services. As RCDC performed both design and construction, 
and contracts were not used, there was little incentive for RDA to improve its competence and 
capacity  in  highway  planning,  management,  and  engineering.  Additionally,  since  much  of 
RCDC’s capacity was taken up with minor works for RDA that were better suited to small-scale 
contractors, and it was not afforded the full autonomy of a private company, RCDC was unable 
to realize its potential for undertaking larger scale, equipment-intensive operations.  
 
15.  Weaknesses in the approach to funding provision of roads have meant that road assets 
are  not  adequately  maintained  and  there  has  not  been  enough  investment  in  capacity 
expansion. Although road user charges generate substantial government revenues, more than 
half  of  these  are  spent  outside  the  road  sector.  The  amount  assigned  to  road  maintenance  is 
much  too  low  compared  with  levels  generally  recommended  for  other  developing  countries. 
Roads do not receive maintenance when needed. Many deteriorate to the extent that they can 
be  restored  to  good  condition  only  by  undertaking  major  rehabilitation  works  at  much  greater 
cost.  An  ADB-funded  TA6  is  to  improve  the  maintenance  budgeting  and  expenditure  control 
system, with a view to determining the full extent of funding shortfalls.

A. 

Project Benefits and Impacts 

87. 
The  beneficiaries  of  the  Project  will  be  people,  companies,  and  government  and 
nongovernment  agencies  throughout  the  country  that  use  road  transport  services  directly  or 
indirectly. The beneficiaries of the investment component will be (i) communities served by the

thereby  obtain  improved  access  to  economic  opportunities  and  social  services,  and  reduced

1. 

Policy and Institutional Aspects 

88. 
The Project and TAs will improve the overall performance of the road sector, contributing 
to  transport  efficiency.  This  will  improve  the  returns  and  sustainability  of  existing  and  future 
investments  in  the  sector,  and  contribute  to  the  growth  of  a  wide  range  of  other  economic 
activities  that  make  use  of  road  transport  services.  Access  to  improved  bus  and  road  freight 
services  will  help  to  reduce  poverty  by  enabling  growth  in  poor  peoples’  incomes  and 
employment, reducing transport services costs, and improving access to social services.  
 
89. 
The  Project  will  open  up  the  market  for  road  provision  works  for  private  sector 
development. This will include increasing the proportion of civil works and engineering assigned 
to  the  domestic  private  sector.  The  Project  will  also  address  issues  of  plant  availability, 
aggregate supply, contractor training, and establishment of private consulting engineering firms. 
Reflecting  the  emphasis  of  the  Project  on  establishing  a  competitive  domestic  private  sector 
capacity, all civil works will be designed for LCB contracts, and no state-owned agencies will be 
eligible to bid. Bus regulation, efficiency of bus operators, and management of bus stations and 
bus stands will also be addressed under the proposed TA. 
 
90. 
Overall, the Project will develop a program of institutional and policy reform for improving 
the  efficiency  of  road  sector  institutions  including  government  agencies,  the  private  sector 
contracting industry, and transport services operators. This will provide the general public with 
efficient transport, the potential contribution to poverty reduction, the scope for increased private 
sector participation, and innovations to improve transparency and governance in general. 
 

2. 

Technical Aspects 

91. 
The  PRI  will  involve  rehabilitation  and  improvement  of  about  980  km  of  roads  in  the 
project  provinces  to  maintainable  standard  roads.  The  existing  roads  will  be  widened  where 
possible; the pavement will be strengthened; and bridges, culverts, and drainage structures will 
also be improved and replaced as necessary.  These will improve the capacity, safety, and level 
of service of the roads. Also, a sustainable road maintenance funding scheme developed under 
the Project will ensure that the existing roads reach their design life.  
 

3. 

Social Aspects 

92. 
Lack of capacity and poor condition of roads are among the main constraints preventing 
poor  people  from  gaining  access  to  economic  opportunities  and  good  quality  services.  The 
Project  will  improve  the  overall  performance  of  the  road  sector,  thereby  alleviating  these 
constraints and contributing to poverty reduction. 
 
The  Project  roads  serve  communities  located  away  from  the  centers  of  economic 
93. 
activity, which have high poverty levels due to a lack of available economic opportunities, poor 
educational attainment, and social problems. Estimated poverty rates in these areas (38%) are 
above the national rates (30%). The poor earn low incomes because they are engaged in poorly 
remunerated  activities  (farm  labor)  or  are  unemployed.  Improvements  in  PRs  will  open  up  the 
communities to a range of new opportunities that will help to reduce poverty. The availability and 
frequency  of  bus  and  road  freight  services  will  increase,  and  the  travel  time  and  cost for the 
services  will  decrease.  The  contributions  to  poverty  reduction  include  (i)  improved  access  for 
farmers  to  higher  price  urban  markets  and  to  produce  higher  value,  perishable  products;  (ii) 
increased  access  to  employment  opportunities  outside  the  community;  (iii)  lower  cost  of 
transport services; and (iv) improved access to education and other social services. The poverty

impact ratios of representative roads for Uva, North Western, and North Central provinces are 
estimated to be more than 0.5, well above the poor's share of national income.  
 
94. 
The  PRI  does  not  require  LAR.  No  new  roads  will  be  developed.  The  works  were 
designed,  using  engineering  solutions,  to  ensure  that  improvements  will  be  within  the  existing 
right-of-way and to avoid resumption of right-of-way if this would cause displacement.  
 
95. 
The  Project  will  generate  direct  and  indirect  employment  opportunities  in  the  private 
sector.  However,  there  will  be  a  gradual  reduction  of  casual  labor  within  RCDC  and  RDA.  A 
transition  plan  is  being  prepared  that  may  include  (i)  freezing  recruitment,  (ii)  early  retirement 
packages,  and  (iii)  incentives  to  private  contractors  to  hire  them.  The  Government  will  ensure 
that the mechanisms of casual labor reduction comply with all applicable labor laws in Sri Lanka 
and take into account ADB’s Social Protection Strategy. 
 

4. 

Economic Aspects 

The overall improvement in the performance of the roads sector will increase transport 
96. 
efficiency. This will improve the returns and sustainability of existing and future investments in 
the sector, and contribute to growth of a wide range of other economic activities that use road 
transport services. Without  the  improvements,  traffic  will  incur  high  transport  operating  costs 
due to poor road conditions. With the improvements, these costs will be reduced.   
 
97. 
The  economic  analysis  (Appendix  18)  of  the  PRI  considers  the  estimated costs and 
benefits over the construction period and 20 years of operation. The estimated costs consist of 
investment costs and incremental operating costs. The estimated benefits are savings in vehicle 
operating  costs  and  passenger  time.  The  estimated  economic  internal  rate  of  return  of  the 
overall Project is 26.1%, or 23.1% for North Central, 21.1% for North Western, 17.8% for Uva, 
and 36.6% for Western provinces. The switching value is 123% for costs and 55% for benefits. 
Sensitivity tests carried out to examine the impact of higher investment costs and lower benefits 
all show an acceptable estimated economic internal rate of return.  
 

5. 

Environmental Aspects 

98. 
The  PRI  is  classified  as  an  environmental  category  B  project.  The initial environmental 
examination  (IEE),  prepared  in  accordance  with  the  ADB  environmental  guidelines,  confirmed 
that  no  significant  adverse  environmental  impacts  are  expected  and  that  a  detailed 
environmental  impact  assessment  is  not  required.  A  supplementary  study  examined  possible 
impacts  on  Sri  Lankan  elephants,  and  found  them  insignificant.  The  PIUs  will  implement 
environmental management and monitoring plans for the road improvements. A Summary IEE 
outlines  the  measures  to  be  incorporated  in  civil  works  contracts  and  to  form  part  of  the 
construction  supervision  team’s  duties  to  mitigate  environmental  impacts  during  construction. 
An  environmental  expert  will  be  hired  under  the  consultant  to  strengthen  the  PRAs  in 
environmental assessment and mitigation. RDA capacity in preconstruction processes, including 
in environmental impact assessment, will be strengthened as necessary. 
 
B. 

Project Risks 

99. 
The significant risk for the Project is that the reform program will not be implemented in 
full, leading to improvements in sector performance being less than intended. This risk has been 
mitigated  in  the  design  of  the  Project  in  accordance  with  the  agreed  upon  medium-term 
program, with milestones that have to be met for future ADB involvement in the sector.

100.  A risk for road investments under the Project is that operation and maintenance will be 
inadequate. This risk will be addressed directly through the reform program elements to improve 
the planning, execution, and financing of road maintenance. These will include (i) strengthening 
of  road  maintenance  management  and  establishing  objective  systems  for  planning  and 
programming road maintenance works on the basis of economic returns; (ii) road maintenance 
works  to  be  undertaken  by  the  private  sector  on  the  basis  of  competition;  and  (iii)  road 
maintenance  budgeting  and  expenditure  control,  and  mechanism 
increasing  road 
maintenance funding to the levels required to sustain the country’s road assets. 
 
101.  The  economic  analysis  of  the  provincial  road  improvements  suggests  there  are  no 
significant  economic  risks.  As  is  generally  expected  in  the  case  for  road  rehabilitation  and 
improvement works of this kind, the estimated economic returns are high.  
 
102.  The main implementation risks for the provincial road improvements concern the limited 
experience  and  capacity  of  contractors.  These  are  mitigated  by  the  relatively  simple  nature  of 
the  works.  Sufficient  provision  has  been  made  for  the  project  implementation  consultant  to 
supervise contractors and provide assistance and training to build up their skills and capacity. 
 
103.  The risk of inadequate counterpart funding has been addressed by gaining government 
commitment to include the Project in its core projects starting in FY2003 to ensure that budget 
allocations for it will be protected.

PRIVATE SECTOR PARTICIPATION ARRANGEMENT S 

 
1. 
The changes in the role of the Road Construction and Development Company (RCDC), 
and  the  development  of  private  sector  participation,  are  intended  to  establish  a  strong, 
competitive  domestic  private  sector  capacity  to  perform  most  of  the  civil  works  and  related 
services  for  highways  administered  by  the  Road  Development  Authority  (RDA).  Since  RCDC 
presently accounts for the majority of domestic capacity, and private sector capacity is limited, it 
will  be  necessary  to  transfer  responsibility  for  road  provision  work  from  RCDC  to  the  private 
sector, and to do so in stages. This will be accomplished over a period of 7 years (from 2002 to 
2008). By the end of that period, RCDC will be performing about 25% of the work financed from 
the  Consolidated  Fund,  and  the  private  sector  will  be  performing  about  75%.  RCDC  will  be 
provided  with  the  full  autonomy  of  a  private  company  to  enable  it  to  realize  its  potential  for 
undertaking larger scale, equipment-intensive operations. 
 
2. 
To  build  up  private  sector  capacity  and  mitigate  the  possible  risks  of  contractor  failure, 
transitional  arrangements  will  be  adopted  for  engaging  private  contractors  during  the  first  3 
years. RCDC will engage private contractors on a subcontract basis, and in doing so will build 
up the capacity of the contractors through on-the-job supervision and training; supplement their 
equipment and other inputs; and guarantee the performance of the works to RDA.
